password_strength.definition: Password strength is a measure of how effective a password is against guessing or brute-force attacks. It's defined by its entropy, not just length or the presence of symbols.

key_factors.title: Key Factors of a Strong Password
key_factors.length: Longer passwords exponentially increase security. 16+ characters is considered strong.
key_factors.character_variety: Includes a mix of lowercase letters (a–z), uppercase letters (A–Z), numbers (0–9), and symbols (!@#$%^&*).
key_factors.unpredictability: Avoids common dictionary words, keyboard patterns (like 'qwerty'), and personal information (like names or dates of birth).

password_entropy.definition: Entropy measures how unpredictable a password is, calculated in 'bits'. It's the most important measure of password strength. It's calculated using the formula: Entropy = length × log₂(character set size).
password_entropy.explanation: Attackers don't guess passwords one-by-one; they use automated tools to try billions per second. Higher entropy means it would take an attacker exponentially longer to guess your password.

scale.title: Approximate Entropy Scale vs. Crack Time
scale.very_weak: A password like 'password123' has about 28 bits of entropy and can be cracked in seconds.
scale.weak: A password like 'P@ssw0rd!' has about 45 bits of entropy and can be cracked in minutes.
scale.strong: A password like 'Tr9#kL2$A8@Qz!eR' has over 100 bits of entropy and would take centuries to crack.

password_entropy.guidance: These are educational estimates assuming a powerful offline attack. The goal is to maximize entropy.

common_mistakes.title: Common Password Mistakes
items: Reusing the same password across multiple websites.
Simply adding a number or symbol at the end of a common word (e.g., 'Password!').
Using any password that has appeared in a known data breach.
Relying on short passwords, even if they seem complex.

password_generator.definition: A password generator is a tool that creates random, high-entropy passwords. They are more secure than passwords created by humans because they avoid the predictable patterns humans naturally use.

rules.title: Rules for a Secure Password Generator
dos: Use a cryptographically secure source of randomness (like the Web Crypto API).
Generate passwords that are at least 16 characters long.
Include a mix of all character sets (uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols).
donts: Generate passwords based on user-provided data.
Reuse patterns or create predictable sequences.

password_managers.definition: Password managers are applications that securely store your passwords for all your different accounts. They can also generate unique, strong passwords for you.
password_managers.recommendation: Using a password manager is the single best practice for password security. It solves the problems of password reuse and the need to remember complex credentials.
password_managers.examples: Popular examples include Bitwarden, 1Password, and KeePass.

passphrases.definition: A passphrase is a sequence of words used as a password. They are often both easier to remember and more secure than traditional complex passwords because their length provides very high entropy.
passphrases.example: A passphrase like 'river-orange-laptop-moon-hammer' is much stronger than a password like 'P@ssw0rd1!', despite being easier to type and remember.
passphrases.recommendation: Using a passphrase, especially when combined with a password manager, is an ideal security practice.

mfa.definition: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds a second layer of security to your accounts. Even if an attacker steals your password, they still can't log in without access to your second factor.
mfa.types: Common second factors include codes from an authenticator app (like Google Authenticator), hardware security keys (like a YubiKey), or biometrics.
mfa.guidance: MFA is a critical security control and should be enabled on all important accounts. It doesn't fix a weak password, but it mitigates the damage if it's stolen.
